importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Houthi rebels' detention of UN employees in Sanaa, marking a significant escalation in the conflict over international humanitarian access in Yemen.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline of events surrounding the raid and detention of UN staff, which occurred within a 24-hour period of a previous UN facility raid, shows a pattern of intensified attacks on UN operations in Yemen.

keyTakeAways: Iranian-backed Houthi rebels detained 20 UN employees in Sanaa, including 5 Yemenis and 15 international staff.
The rebels confiscated all communication equipment from the facility, including phones, servers, and computers.
The detained employees belong to multiple UN agencies, including the World Food Program, UNICEF, and the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.
The Houthis have launched a long-running crackdown against UN and international organizations in Sanaa, Hodeida, and Saada province.
Over 50 UN staff have been detained in total, including a World Food Program worker who died in detention earlier this year in Saada.
The UN has suspended operations in Saada province and relocated its top humanitarian coordinator from Sanaa to Aden.
The Houthis have repeatedly alleged that UN staff are spies, though the UN has strongly denied these accusations.
The UN is actively engaging with the Houthis and other parties to resolve the crisis, end detentions, and restore full control over its facilities in Sanaa.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Iranian-backed Houthi rebels in Yemen detained 20 UN employees, including five Yemenis and 15 international staff, in Sanaa on October 19, 2025, following a prior raid. The rebels confiscated all communication equipment from the facility, including phones and computers. The detained staff come from multiple UN agencies, including the World Food Program, UNICEF, and OCHA. This marks part of a sustained crackdown by the Houthis on UN and humanitarian operations in Sanaa, Hodeida, and Saada, where over 50 staff have been detained, and a WFP worker died in detention earlier this year. The UN has suspended operations in Saada and relocated its top humanitarian coordinator to Aden, while urgently seeking negotiations to end detentions and restore access to facilities. The Houthis have repeatedly accused detained staff of being spies, a claim the UN has strongly denied.
